items.description: River Thames and its tributaries from Days Lock to above Pangbourne

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Lady Brook, Ewelme Stream, Mill Brook, West Hagbourne Stream, Hakkas Brook, Cholsey Brook, Kibble Ditch

items.message:
River levels on the Mill Brook, a tributary of the River Thames, are high as a result of heavy rain. Therefore, flooding of low lying land, roads and property is expected to continue today 24/09/2024, especially in the areas closest to the Mill Brook in the Blewbury and South Moreton areas. Levels on the River Thames remain below the flood risk threshold. 
The forecast is for a predominantly dry day today 24/09/24. River levels are currently gradually falling but will remain sensitive to further rainfall. 
Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens in the area and we are closely monitoring the situation. We are operating our weirs on the Thames to manage flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by this evening, 24/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Cuckmere River
items.message: After Sunday evening's rain, the Cuckmere and Bull Rivers have now fallen significantly through Hellingly. In Alfriston, the Cuckmere River is still higher than normal, but is now falling and not expected to be causing property flooding. Some minor flood impacts could remain, with small amount of water affecting fields and roads. Only isolated showers are forecast Tuesday. The rivers should continue to fall. However a lot of rain is forecast Wednesday afternoon and evening. There remains uncertainty in details of locations and amounts, but there is the potential for flood risk to return. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road Hellingly and North Street Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if confidence increases and new flooding is thought possible.

items.description: Upper Nene
items.message: Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the Upper River Nene area. This means that the River Nene is rising, which will lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river from the evening of Monday 23rd September onwards. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts also indicate that flooding inside properties is likely and therefore a flood warning has been issued for areas near the Dallington Brook and Brampton Branch in Northampton. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 20:00 on 24/09/2024, or before if the situation changes.

We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington. No further rainfall is forecast. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 12:00 on 25/09/24, or as the situation changes.

We are monitoring the situation. 

We will update this message by 6pm today, 24/09/2024.

items.description: Chertsey Bourne

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen on the Chertsey Bourne as a result of heavy rain over the weekend and yesterday. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected today 24/09/2024, especially in the areas closest to the Free Prae Road area of Chertsey.
Today is forecast to be mainly dry with the possibility of light scattered showers. Further heavier rainfall is forecast tomorrow 25/09/24. River levels have started to stabilise and level off, although we expect levels to remain high for several days. 
Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 25/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Gloucestershire
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Tewkesbury Upper Pound river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected from 10am tomorrow, 24/09/2024. 
We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill. 
Predicted peaks:- Mythe 2.8m to 3.3m 25/09, Haw Bridge 3.5m to 4.0m 25/09, Sandhurst 2.5m to 3.0m 25/09, Gloucester 2.0m to 2.5m 25/09. 
No further significant rainfall is forecast in the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 12:00 Today, 24/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Adur East Branch
items.message: Another 10mm of rain was recorded Monday night. The River Adur is rising again. Minor flood impacts could affect the fields and roads, although river levels are expected to peak a little lower than they were on Monday. Only isolated showers are forecast Tuesday. The river should begin to fall by 17:00 24/09/2024, and should return to normal from 11:00 25/09/2024. However a lot of rain is forecast Wednesday afternoon and evening. There remains uncertainty in details of locations and amounts, but there is the potential for flood risk to return. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may be affected, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 25/09/2024.

Areas most at risk are Towcester Mill, Northampton Road between Stoke Bruerne and Grafton Regis, Bozenham Mill Lane, Castlethorpe Mill, and The Priory and Leisure Park at Cosgrove. 
 
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours which will keep river levels high.  
 
Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don’t put yourself in unnecessary danger.  
 
We are monitoring the situation.  
 
We will update this message by 6pm today, 24/09/2024.

items.description: River Nene at Billing Aquadrome and nearby business parks
items.message: Heavy rain has fallen in the Nene catchment over the last 48 hours. This is causing the River Nene to rise and is forecast to continue to rise through the day. Low lying areas near the River are already flooded and we now expect properties at Billing Aquadrome to be affected from this afternoon onwards. No further rainfall is expected today however river levels are expected to continue to rise. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. Please avoid contact with flood water.  Our staff are out in the area to check the flood defences, clear blockages, and assist the emergency services and council. We will be closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 17:00 on 25/09/24, or before if the situation changes.
